HOUSE OF COMMONS

Wednesday, February 16. 1948

The house met at three o’clock.

INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS

AMENDMENT or CHAPTER 54, STATUTES or 1947—48—DEDUCTION or UNION DUES

Mr. Arthur Williams (Ontario) moved for leave to introduce Bill No. 19, to amend the Industrial Relations and Disputes Investiga- tion Act (deduction of union dues).

Some hon. Members: Explain.

Mr. Williams: The purpose of this bill is to amend the federal labour code, which was adopted last year, by adding a new subsection 3 to section 6 of the act. The effect of the new subsection is to provide for the revocable voluntary check-oft of union dues.

Motion agreed to and bill read the ﬁrst time.

AMENDMENT or CHAPTER 54, STATUTES or 1947-48—ENEORCEMENT REGULATIONS

Mr. Clarence Gillis (Cape Breton South) moved for leave to introduce Bill No. 20, to amend the Industrial Relations and Disputes Investigation Act (enforcement).

Motion agreed to and bill read the ﬁrst time.

AMENDMENT or CHAPTER 54, STATUTES or 1947-48—nErmrr10N or EMPLOYEE

Mr. Stanley Knowles (Winnipeg North Centre) moved for leave to introduce Bill No. 21, to amend the Industrial Relations and Disputes Investigation Act (deﬁnition of employee).

Some hon. Members: Explain.

Mr. Knowles: This bill deletes a portion of subparagraph (i) of subsection 1 of section 2 of the federal labour code in which employees are deﬁned. Its purpose is to remove a dis- crimination against certain groups of em— ployees. In other words the bill would afford to certain categories ot employees, now excluded from the provisions of the act, the right of collective bargaining.

Motion agreed to and bill read the ﬁrst time.

PENSION FUND SOCIETIES ACT

EXTENSION 0F PROVISIONS T0 OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES OF SUBSIDIARY CORPORATIONS

Hon. Douglas Abbott (Minister of Finance) moved the ﬁrst reading of Bill No. 18 (from the Senate) to amend the Pension Fund Societies Act.

Motion agreed to and bill read the ﬁrst time.

VAL D’OR, PONTIAC COUNTY, POST OFFICE

Mr. Caouette:

1. Have tenders been called for the construction of a post ofﬁce at Val d’Or. in the county of Pontiac?

2. If so. on what date?

3. Up to what date could tenders be submitted?

4. What are the names of those who tendered and the amount of the respective tenders?

5. To whom was the contract awarded and on what conditions?

Mr. Fournier (Hull):

1. Yes.

2. December 13, 1948.

3. January 12, 1949.

4. (a) Alphonse Gratton Inc., 3440 Shuter St., Montreal, P.Q., $243,283; (b) J. A. Tremb- lay, Bourlamaque, P.Q., $246,000; (c) Paul L’Ecuyer, Val d’Or, P.Q., $246,000; ((1) Hill— Clark-Francis Limited, Noranda, P.Q., $249,550; (e) Frs. Marquis & Fils Limitée, Quebec, P.Q., $258,000; (f) Sauriol Construc- tion Company, Gatineau, P.Q., $309,000.

5. Recommendation has been submitted to council on the 15th instant for authority to award the contract to the lowest tenderer.
